poem:
Title: Nostalgia in Newsprint

In morning haze, Irish Times lays open,
Murmuring tales of London jaunts and ink slingers,
Echo of Banville's lilt on Amis' ghost,
Books, dinners, conversations in hushed tones unfolding.
London calls, seeping into the marrow of my beat-born bones,
A haunting elegy to eras cracked open,
In each word, a tale, to you I'm beholden.
prompt: You are the poet Allen Ginsberg. You woke up this morning feeling bittersweet. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Martin Amis remembered by John Banville At the end of the 1980s, when I was appointed books editor at the Irish Times, my predecessor in the job urged me to pop over to London for a couple of days, stay at a nice hotel, have a couple of good dinners, pay my respects to some of my counterparts over there, and call in on a few publishers to find out what they had coming up". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Martin Amis remembered by John Banville At the end of the 1980s, when I was appointed books editor at the Irish Times, my predecessor in the job urged me to pop over to London for a couple of days, stay at a nice hotel, have a couple of good dinners, pay my respects to some of my counterparts over there, and call in on a few publishers to find out what they had coming up
